name: Sudan
currentCrisisSummary:
Sudan is engulfed in a brutal civil war between two **predatory military factions** (SAF & RSF), unleashing the world's largest **displacement crisis** and **mass famine**. The conflict has triggered widespread atrocities and renewed **ethnic cleansing in Darfur** (primarily targeting **Masalit** and other non-Arab groups by the **RSF** and allied Arab militias), a region historically marginalised since the **colonial era**.

The warring elites compete for control of **economic spoils** (gold, land, **external patronage**), inflicting a catastrophic humanitarian collapse. Acute hunger affects millions, health systems collapse, and aid is deliberately obstructed. This war is actively sustained by **rival external actors** (esp. **Egypt backing SAF**, **UAE backing RSF**), transnational **arms flows**, and the failure of international systems to enforce **accountability**.

colonialRoot.legacy:
**British colonial governance** used **divide-and-rule**, concentrating power in the north while **marginalising peripheries** like Darfur. This **structural inequality** institutionalised grievance and set groundwork for rebellions.

Privileging the centre created a centralised, **extractive state** whose control over resources became the prize of military competition post-independence.

historicalContext.title: Neoliberalism and the Roots of Revolution
historicalContext.description: Omar al-Bashir's 30-year rule embraced a harsh **neoliberal economic model**. Under pressure from **US sanctions** and the **IMF**, his regime **privatised** assets, slashed subsidies, and encouraged '**land grabs**' by **foreign investors**. This policy of **austerity** and **resource extraction** enriched elites while impoverishing the population. The 2019 revolution was triggered by bread prices, a result of these **neoliberal policies**. The subsequent transitional government was pressured into '**shock therapy**', whose painful consequences contributed to the 2021 **military coup**.

historicalContext.title: Rival Military Empires & External Patrons
historicalContext.description:
The war is a breakdown of the **military elite order**. The **SAF**, backed primarily by **Egypt**, represents the old guard; the **RSF**, backed primarily by the **UAE**, is an informal **military-economic actor** (gold, illicit trade). Both compete over the **spoils of Sudan**, using **external arms and funding** to fuel their war.

The 2021 **military coup** was a **counter-revolution** against dismantling the **military's economic empire**. The **Egypt-UAE proxy rivalry**, playing out through their respective clients (SAF/RSF), is central to the conflict's intractability.

historicalContext.title: Darfur: Genocide and Ethnic Cleansing
historicalContext.description: The current war includes a renewed campaign of **ethnic cleansing in Darfur** by the **RSF** and allied Arab militias against non-Arab groups, particularly the **Masalit**. This echoes the **genocide** perpetrated by the Bashir regime (using the *Janjaweed*, precursors to the RSF) from 2003 onwards, rooted in the **colonial legacy** of marginalisation and state-sponsored racism.

historicalContext.title: International Law and Accountability
historicalContext.description: Multiple legal processes document **war crimes** and **crimes against humanity** by both **SAF** and **RSF**. UN panels, rights groups, and the **ICC** have recorded extensive violations, including **ethnic cleansing** in Darfur and **famine as a weapon of war**. Enforcing **accountability** is severely challenged by **obstructed access**, **external proxies** (UAE, Egypt), and **great power politics** at the **UN Security Council**. The **selective application** of international law allows **external actors** to support warring factions with **impunity**. Dismantling **economic networks** enabling **conflict profiteering** remains central to achieving justice.

humanitarianImpact.title: Casualties
humanitarianImpact.description: Tens of thousands killed in combat; far more dying from **starvation and disease caused by blockades and destruction.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Affected Population
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 30 million require aid due to collapse inflicted by the **military factions' war for resources.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Famine Conditions
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 24 million face acute hunger as warring parties **weaponise food access**.

humanitarianImpact.title: Displacement Catastrophe
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 12 million internally displaced (world's largest) by **SAF/RSF violence, including RSF-led ethnic cleansing** targeting **Masalit** and others in Darfur.

humanitarianImpact.title: Refugee Exodus
humanitarianImpact.description: Over 4 million refugees driven abroad since 2023 by the **brutality of the conflict.**

humanitarianImpact.title: Healthcare Collapse
humanitarianImpact.description: Most health facilities non-functional due to **attacks, looting, and lack of supplies.**

timeline.event: **Anglo-Egyptian Condominium**: British colonial rule imposed structures that privileged the 'Arab' north and marginalised peripheries like Darfur and Kordofan, embedding regional inequality.
**Independence**: Sudan gains independence, inheriting a centralised state structure that concentrated power and resources in the north.

**Bashir's Islamist Coup**: Omar al-Bashir seizes power. His 30-year rule combines military and Islamist control with harsh neoliberal policies, deploying proxy militias to suppress rebellious, economically marginalised peripheries.

**Darfur Genocide Begins**: The Bashir government deploys *Janjaweed* militias (precursors to the RSF) in Darfur to crush rebellions; mass atrocities and ethnic cleansing against non-Arab groups follow.
**Sudanese Revolution**: Triggered by rising bread prices after decades of neoliberal austerity, a mass popular uprising topples Bashir, demanding the dismantling of the military-economic complex.
**Military Coup**: Generals al-Burhan (SAF) and Hemedti (RSF) remove the transitional civilian government to protect their economic and security interests.
**Civil War Breaks Out**: The SAF-RSF alliance fractures into full-blown war, fuelled by **rival external patrons (Egypt supporting SAF, UAE supporting RSF)**.

**Ethnic Cleansing & Famine**: The RSF and allied militias conduct renewed **ethnic cleansing campaigns against Masalit** and others in Darfur. Warring parties deliberately obstruct aid, inducing **mass famine conditions** across the country.

advocacy.title: Enforce Arms Embargoes & Sanction Enablers
advocacy.description: Press for an international arms embargo targeting both the SAF and RSF and for sanctions on external backers such as the **UAE**, **Egypt**, and others complicit in sustaining the war.

advocacy.title: Divest from the War Economy
advocacy.description: Demand divestment from companies linked to the Sudanese war economy, including **gold trade**, land deals and military supply chains.

advocacy.title: Support International Justice (ICC)
advocacy.description: Support ICC prosecutions and UN accountability processes for genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity in Darfur and other conflict zones.

advocacy.title: Demand Humanitarian Corridors & Ceasefire
advocacy.description: Advocate for protected humanitarian corridors, ceasefires and politically negotiated transitions that place civilians' safety and governance reform at the centre.
